item.title: Mysql Container
item.description: Install mysql as container shell> docker pull mysql/mysql-server shell> docker images shell> docker run --name=mysql1 -d mysql/mysql-server It generates default root password shell> docker logs mysql1 use generated password for login by root user shell> docker logs mysql1 2>&1 | grep GENERATED GENERATED ROOT PASSWORD: Axegh3kAJyDLaRuBemecis&EShOs Connecting to MySQL Server from within the Container docker exec -it mysql1 mysql -uroot -p by password: Axegh3kAJyDLaRuBemecis&EShOs. Since we cannot query, we have to change default password

item.title: Serving deep learning models in production
item.description: Shipping deep learning models to production is a non-trivial task. There are many solutions out there which use cloud service providers from Google or Amazon. However, I am curious those processes, thus I want to learn them and design my serving system. Since I do not favor any specific solution, I outline the following problems which need to be solved in designing a deep learning serving system: Real-time collecting from various sources.

Keep it simple, but not simpler Hi, I’m Kha Nguyen. I’m a web security researcher. Occasionally, I share my thoughts on programming, ctf write-up and life experiences right here on my blog. Follow my journey through this new blog.
